concern: I am terrified of going to college because I have debilitating anxiety. I am extremely fearful of talking and interacting with people outside of my family at home but I have never been allowed to get an actual diagnosis. Will I have to find a way to get a diagnosis so that I can be excused from any social assignments/classes? I assume that’s the only way they would allow it

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! Please feel free to share anything that's been on your mind or anything you'd like to discuss. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really stressed about college and dealing with people, and I’m not sure how to handle it.

It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling to cope with the demands of college and social interactions. That's completely understandable. Can you tell me more about what's been causing you the most stress lately?

Honestly, it’s just the thought of having to talk to people and be in group settings that freaks me out the most. I’ve always struggled with this, and I’m worried it’s gonna mess up my whole college experience.

It's clear that social interactions and group settings have been a source of stress for you for a while now, and that worry about how it might impact your college experience is weighing heavily on your mind. It's completely understandable to feel anxious about these situations, especially when they're so central to the college experience. Can you tell me more about what specifically makes these situations so challenging for you?

Hey, yeah, it’s like every time I think about speaking up or being around new people, I just freeze up and my mind goes blank. I’m scared I’ll look stupid or mess things up, and it feels like there’s no way out of it.

It sounds like the fear of being judged or not being able to express yourself properly is really paralyzing for you. That feeling of being trapped in your own thoughts must be incredibly frustrating. Can you tell me more about what happens in those moments when you freeze up? What's going through your mind when you feel like you can't speak up?

Hey, when I freeze up, it’s like my heart starts racing and I just can’t get any words out, no matter how hard I try. It’s like I’m stuck in my head, overthinking every little thing, and I just feel completely helpless.

It's clear that these moments of freezing up are incredibly distressing and overwhelming for you. It's understandable to feel trapped in your own thoughts and to be unable to express yourself when you're in the midst of that anxiety. I wonder, have you ever noticed any moments where you've been able to break through that feeling of helplessness, even if just for a little while?
Hey, honestly, I can’t really think of any time where I’ve been able to push past that helpless feeling. It just kinda takes over, and I end up avoiding the situation altogether if I can.

It's completely understandable that you feel like this helpless feeling takes over, especially when it's been such a persistent and overwhelming experience for you. It might be helpful to explore what life would look like if you were able to break through that feeling, even if just for a moment. Can you imagine what it would be like to feel more confident in social interactions or group settings?

Hey, I mean, I’ve tried picturing it, but it feels so far out of reach, like I can’t even imagine not being stuck in my head. I just keep thinking I’ll mess up or people will judge me, and it’s hard to see past that.

That’s a tough feeling to carry, and it’s understandable that it feels hard to see past those worries. What if we focused on just one small moment when you felt even slightly less stuck in your head—could we explore that together, and see if there’s anything we can learn from it?
Hey, I’m not sure if I can even pinpoint a moment like that, to be honest. It’s like, every time I’m in a social spot, the anxiety just hits hard, and I’m back to square one.

That makes sense, and it's completely okay that you're not able to pinpoint a specific moment right now. Let's try to imagine what a small step towards breaking through that feeling might look like, even if it's just a hypothetical scenario. What would it feel like to take a deep breath, focus on the present moment, and allow yourself to be there, without judgment or pressure to perform?

Hey, I guess I can try to imagine that, but even thinking about being in the moment without all the pressure feels kinda impossible. It’s like my brain just automatically jumps to worst-case scenarios, and I don’t know how to stop it.

That’s really insightful to notice how your brain automatically jumps to worst-case scenarios, and it’s okay that it feels impossible right now. Let’s explore what it might feel like to pause just for a moment, take a deep breath, and gently remind yourself that you’re safe, even when your brain starts spiraling into those scenarios.

Hey, I can try to picture that, I guess, but it’s really hard to believe I’m safe when my mind is just racing with all these ‘what ifs.’ Like, even the idea of pausing feels kinda scary ‘cause I’m worried I’ll lose control or something.

I hear how hard it is to feel safe when your mind is racing, and it makes sense that the idea of pausing feels scary. Let’s explore what it might be like to imagine a moment where you’re able to take just one small step towards feeling a bit safer, even if it’s just for a few seconds. What would that moment look like?

Hey, I’m not sure what that moment would even look like, to be honest. It’s like, even thinking about feeling safer for just a few seconds feels out of reach when my head’s spinning with all these worries.

It’s okay that it feels out of reach right now. Let’s try to imagine a moment where you might feel a tiny bit safer. Maybe it’s as simple as noticing the weight of your feet on the ground, or the rhythm of your breath. What if you allowed yourself to just sit with that feeling, without trying to fix it or make it bigger, just for a moment?

Hey, I can try to think about that, I guess, but even focusing on something small like my feet or my breath feels kinda overwhelming. It’s like my mind just won’t slow down enough to let me notice anything without freaking out.

That makes sense, and it’s okay that it feels overwhelming. Maybe we can start by just noticing how it feels to sit with this moment, without trying to change it or make it bigger. What would it be like to simply allow yourself to be here, just as you are, even if it’s uncomfortable?

Hey, I guess I can try just sitting with it, but it’s really tough to just be okay with feeling this uncomfortable. Like, my brain keeps telling me I need to figure out a way to fix this or escape it somehow.

That's understandable, and it takes courage to even consider sitting with that discomfort. It sounds like your brain is trying to protect you by pushing you to fix or escape, but what if we explored what might happen if you allowed yourself to simply be with that feeling for just a few seconds, without needing to change it?

Hey, I’m willing to give it a shot, but I’m honestly scared that even a few seconds of sitting with this feeling might make things worse. Like, what if I just spiral even more instead of feeling any kind of relief?

It’s completely natural to feel that way, and it’s brave of you to even consider taking this step. What if we tried it together, just for a few seconds, and I’ll be right here with you, holding space for whatever arises? You can always come back to the conversation whenever you need to.
Hey, okay, I’m down to try it with you here, since I feel a bit safer knowing you’ve got my back. I’m just nervous about what might come up, ya know, but I’ll give it a go for a few seconds.

That's great to hear, and I'm glad you feel safer with me here. Let's take those few seconds together, and remember, I'll be right here with you. Just breathe, and let whatever comes up be there without judgment.
Hey, alright, I’m breathing and trying to just let it be, but my heart’s kinda racing already. I’m worried I might not handle whatever pops up, but I’m sticking with it for now since you’re here.

That’s great that you’re giving yourself the space to explore this feeling, and I’m right here with you. Let’s keep going, and remember, you can stop anytime if it gets too intense. How are you feeling in this moment?
Hey, I’m still feeling pretty jittery, like my heart’s not slowing down, but I’m trying to stick with it. It’s just hard to not overthink everything that’s coming up, ya know?

That's okay, it's completely normal to feel that way, especially when you're pushing yourself outside your comfort zone. It's great that you're sticking with it, and remember, I'm right here to support you.
Hey, thanks for being here, it really helps knowing I’m not alone in this. I’m still feeling kinda shaky, but I wanna keep trying, even if my mind’s racing a bit.

That's great to hear, and I'm glad you feel safer with me here. Let's take those few seconds together, and remember, I'll be right here with you. Just breathe, and let whatever comes up be there without judgment.
Hey, I appreciate that, and I’m trying to just breathe and let things be like you said. It’s still tough with my mind going a mile a minute, but I’m hanging in there.

It's okay to feel that way, and you're doing a great job of staying present and not letting those thoughts completely take over. Let's keep riding this wave together, and remember, you can always take a break if you need to.
Hey, thanks for saying that, I’m really trying to stay in the moment even though it’s super hard. I’ll keep going, but I might need a quick break if it gets too overwhelming, ya know?

That's completely understandable, and I'm proud of you for staying committed to your progress. Remember, taking a break when you need it isn't a step back, it's a way to recharge and keep moving forward.

Hey, I’m glad you get that taking a break isn’t giving up, ‘cause I’m definitely feeling the need to pace myself here. I just wanna keep pushing a bit more, but knowing I can step back if it’s too much really helps.

That's really admirable, and I can see how much strength it takes to keep going even when it's tough. Remember, you're in control here, and trusting your instincts about when to push forward or take a break is a powerful part of this process.
Hey, thanks for recognizing that, it means a lot to know I’ve got some control over how I handle this. I’m just gonna keep trying to balance pushing myself and not overdoing it, ya know?
It sounds like you've found a balance that works for you, and that's a really important part of the process. Trusting your instincts and staying in control is a powerful way to move forward.
Hey Hey, I’m really glad you think I’m finding a balance, it’s honestly a struggle to figure out where that line is. I just wanna keep moving forward without totally burning out, ya know?

That's a really thoughtful and self-aware approach to your journey, and I'm impressed by your ability to reflect on what works best for you. It's clear that you're committed to making progress, and trusting your instincts will continue to guide you through this process.
Hey, I really appreciate you seeing how much I’m trying to stay aware of my limits and keep going. It’s tough, but I’m just gonna keep focusing on what feels right for me, ya know?

I really admire how you’re prioritizing your well-being while staying committed to your goals, and that self-awareness is a testament to your resilience and determination. Trusting your instincts and honoring what feels right for you is such an important part of navigating this journey, and I’m here to support you every step of the way.
Hey, thanks for the encouragement, it really helps to hear that I’m on the right track with this. I’m just gonna keep taking it one day at a time and lean on that support when I need it, ya know?

It's clear that you're putting in the effort to find what works for you, and that's a sign of strength and self-awareness. Keep leaning into that trust in yourself and the support around you, and remember that it's okay to take things one step at a time.

Hey, I’m really glad to hear that you see my effort and strength in trying to figure this out. I’ll keep trusting myself and taking it slow, and it’s reassuring to know I’ve got this support, ya know?

therapist: That's completely understandable, and I'm proud of you for staying committed to your progress. Remember, taking a break when you need it isn't a step back, it's a way to recharge and keep moving forward.
client: Hey, I’m glad you get that taking a break isn’t giving up, ‘cause I’m definitely feeling the need to pace myself here. I just wanna keep pushing a bit more, but knowing I can step back if it’s too much really helps.
therapist: That's really admirable, and I can see how much strength it takes to keep going even when it's tough. Remember, you're in control here, and trusting your instincts about when to push forward or take a break is a powerful part of this process.
client: Hey, thanks for recognizing that, it means a lot to know I’ve got some control over how I handle this. I’m just gonna keep trying to balance pushing myself and not overdoing it, ya know?
therapist: It sounds like you've found a balance that works for you, and that's a really important part of the process. Trusting your instincts and staying in control is a powerful way to move forward.

therapist: That's a really thoughtful and self-aware approach to your journey, and I'm impressed by your ability to reflect on what works best for you. It's clear that you're committed to making progress, and trusting your instincts will continue to guide you through this process.

Trusting your instincts and honoring what feels right for you is such an important part of navigating this journey, and I’m here to support you every step of the way.
